text: The negative regulatory element ( NRE ) of the hepatitis B virus ( HBV ) core promoter contains three subregions which act synergistically to suppress core promoter activity .
One of these subregions , NRE gamma , is active in both HeLa cervical carcinoma cells and Huh7 hepatoma cells and was found to be bound by a protein factor present in both cell types .
Here we show that the transcription factor <extra_id_0> RFX1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can bind to NRE gamma and transactivate the core promoter through this site .
Mutations which abrogated the gene-suppressive activity of NRE gamma prevented <extra_id_0> RFX1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> from binding to NRE gamma .

text: In addition , <extra_id_0> RFX1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can bind simultaneously , most likely as a heterodimer , with the transcription factor <extra_id_0> MIBP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to NRE gamma .

text: In the absence of a cloned <extra_id_0> MIBP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene for further studies , we hypothesize that <extra_id_0> RFX1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> acts with <extra_id_0> MIBP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to negatively regulate the core promoter activity through the NRE gamma site .

The ability of <extra_id_0> RFX1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to transactivate the core promoter raises the possibility that <extra_id_0> RFX1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may play a dual role in regulating HBV gene expression .
